where_to_read: Hi ho, hi ho, its off to work we go

reviews.review_text: One of my daughter's favorite books.

There has been numerous essays, papers and books interpreting Salingers various works. I am not going to add to them. Take up and read for yourself and see what you discover. Then have another person read and then talk about your insights. Much more interesting than mind numbing stories found on TV!

I love this book. Have read the paperback countless times. So this review is on the Kindle version, which I purchased as my original has been read so often it is dog-eared and falling apart. The Kindle version is a mess and almost unreadable. Zero care was put into the formatting, leading to words being hyphenated in the middle of sentences (when my guess is that in the book they were hyphenated at the end of the printed line). Some pages loses their formatting halfway through and suddenly read like a haiku. I can't even read this version as it pulls me out of the story completely. This book deserved better treatment.

I have to admit that I found most of this book disturbing because the characters are so unlikeable.Zooey is worst. He is so smug and sarcastic, I cringed on almost all the words he spoke. The way in which he addressed his mother was, frankly just awful to read. And she isn’t that likable either. The grown children in this story almost seem like today’s millennials – so disillusioned and unhappy, even with all the blessings they have.  Spoiler alert: Even though both Franny and Zooey seem to have some type of positive epiphany at the end, I’m not hopeful it will last for them. They’re just too entitled. That’s about all the story is: a story of entitled people
It's a wonderful 5-star book, as always, but the Kindle version has a lot of formatting problems. Try the sample first and see how much they bother you.
I don't love it, but i like it!

A short novel of voice that consists of three conversations and little else. I prefer the Franny portion on its own, but I liked the resolution that I got from the final third of this book. My god are Zooey and his mom in that bathroom for a long time. Mostly love it for the way it wades into the waters of esotericism and for a family that reads as the literary antecedent of the Royal Tenenbaums.
One of my all-time favorites.  Better than "Catcher in the Rye."  Deeper and more subtle.
One of my favorite books, perfect beach/hammock read :)
I love this book. J.d. Salinger is a genius!

title: Franny and Zooey

summary: The author writes: FRANNY came out in The New Yorker in 1955, and was swiftly followed, in 1957 by ZOOEY. Both stories are early, critical entries in a narrative series I'm doing about a family of settlers in twentieth-century New York, the Glasses. It is a long-term project, patently an ambiguous one, and there is a real-enough danger, I suppose that sooner or later I'll bog down, perhaps disappear entirely, in my own methods, locutions, and mannerisms. On the whole, though, I'm very hopeful. I love working on these Glass stories, I've been waiting for them most of my life, and I think I have fairly decent, monomaniacal plans to finish them with due care and all-available skill.
story_arc:
Fortunes fall, but the protagonist
                    bounces back
